results.title: Ararat
results.brief_description: When Noel Matthews watched this old film to see if it could go into the MAP project he realised that it was of enormous personal significance to him. This footage of Ararat township circa 1930 is combined with a voiceover by Noel explaining why watching this film had such a powerful effect. One of earliest submissions to the MAP project.

results.title: North
results.creator_credit: Christos Linou, Christos Tsiolkas and Spiro Economopolous
results.brief_description: Collingwood - ‘Hit the North. The north is where they put most of the wogs.’ Utilising excerpts from Christos Tsiolkas’ novel ‘Loaded’, ‘North’ is a lyrical and haunting work about space and place in Melbourne’s inner-city northern suburbs. This short work reveals a history of migrant alienation and regret submerged underneath the asphalt, mortar and concrete of the modern Australian city.

results.title: Kill the day
results.brief_description: An evocative study of a man just released from prison, Kill the Day is an evocative study of the “prison” formed by poverty and social deprivation. As in her other award winning shorts, Lynne Ramsey’s focus is not on the melodramatic but on the everyday poetics of working class Glaswegian life. By concentrating on the day to day activities of her main character, and by situating him in a realistically observed personal and social milieu, she shows herself to be not only influenced by filmmakers such as Mike Leigh and Robert Bresson, but as a uniquely inspired filmmaker in her own right.

results.title: The Digital Environment - Information about Australia's Culture and New Technologies
results.brief_description:
This CD provides an information resource about the intersection of new technologies and cultural activities including: web-publishing, copyright, interoperability, digitisation and other aspects of the Internet age.

Extensive video, reports, discussion papaers, glossaries and other material are available on the CD. There is a powerful index to search thense resources, and it contains hyperlinks to quickly access documents on the Web if your computer has an Internet connection.

results.title: Come out fighting
results.brief_description: A young Aboriginal boxer is taken up by University students and finds it hard to adjust entering their bourgeois white world. This short is ragged and rough around the edges but it offers a rivetting glimpse into black and white relations in the early seventies, as well as some wonderful realistic sequences set in inner-city boxing gyms.

results.title: Dalai Lama in Australia production
results.brief_description:
An audio visual recording of the following events as part of the visit to Australia in May 2002 by His Holiness the 14th Dalai Lama of Tibet:

4.00 pm Sunday 19th May 2002: Public Talk by Dalai Lama

8.30 am Monday 20th May 2002: Teaching by Dalai Lama: Atisha’s,
A Lamp to the Path to Enlightenment.

11.15 am Monday 20th May 2002: Victorian Secondary Schools
Event with the Dalai Lama and Sigrid Thornton as MC.
5 Students will ask questions of the Dalai Lama.

2.00 pm Monday 20th May 2002: Teaching by the Dalai Lama:
Atisha’s Lamp to the Path to Enlightenment

9.30 am Tuesday 21st May 2002: Teaching by the Dalai Lama:
Atisha’s Lamp to the Path to Enlightenment

2.00 pm Tuesday 21st May 2002: Teaching by the Dalai Lama:
Atisha’s Lamp to the Path to Enlightenment

9.30 am Wednesday 22nd May 2002: Semkye and Chenrezig Jenang
Empowerment by the Dalai Lama

2.00 pm Wednesday 22nd May 2002: Teaching by the Dalai Lama:
Atisha’s Lamp to the Path to Enlightement

results.title: Spitfire 123
results.material_description: Multi-channel installation, video, monitors, colour and audio
results.brief_description: The third in an ongoing six-part series collectively titled ‘From the Darwin Translations’. This series, like Jones’ previous projects, shifts between installation, video, and performance, in an exploration of human (sexual) attraction. The installation spans two rooms, one with a large screen and another with three video monitors. The monitor room shows a more meditative, transitional space, ‘poppy fields’; a repeating image series of swaying poppies, accompanied by the rustle of wind, bird song and insect noises and interrupted now and then by the roar of airplanes flying overhead. The large screen in the other room presents, ‘Spitfire’, showing shots from the cockpit of the legendary World War II fighter plane, accompanied by engine-sounds, dramatic computerized noises and oscillating-music, as well as whispering voices. Sky and land spiral, falter, and blur as intimate fantasies are imparted. Thus the result is fragmented and disorientating. The position of the audience shifts between that of voyeur and that of participant. She threatens to undo you with the romance of memory, aeroplanes and youth; you have to look, listen and feel.
